title: A comprehensive SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19 review, Part 1: Intracellular overdrive for SARS-CoV-2 infection
background: SARS-CoV-2 has caused a global pandemic with significant morbidity and mortality. Understanding the virus's intracellular mechanisms is critical for developing countermeasures, particularly for spaceflight where immune system changes and limited medical resources pose additional risks.
objective: To comprehensively review SARS-CoV-2's intracellular infection mechanisms, including viral entry, host cell hijacking, metabolic reprogramming, and immune evasion strategies relevant to understanding viral pathogenesis in constrained environments.
methods: Comprehensive literature review integrating evidence from patient samples, organoid models, cell culture studies, and animal models to elucidate SARS-CoV-2 intracellular infection mechanisms and host responses.
results: SARS-CoV-2 extensively reprograms host cell metabolism, suppresses mitochondrial function, dysregulates calcium signaling, and evades innate immune responses through multiple viral proteins that interact with host cellular machinery.
conclusion: SARS-CoV-2 employs sophisticated intracellular strategies to hijack host cell functions, with implications for understanding viral pathogenesis in spaceflight conditions where immune and metabolic systems are already stressed.

learning_notes.note: SARS-CoV-2 infection causes heavy suppression of mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation genes across multiple organs, with viral proteins interacting directly with mitochondrial complex I assembly factors (NDUFAF1, NDUFAF2, NDUFB9), suggesting mitochondrial dysfunction as a central mechanism in COVID-19 pathology relevant to spaceflight metabolic stress.

The virus induces a metabolic shift to glycolysis (Warburg effect) and increases HIF-1α stability, with ORF3a protein inducing mitochondrial ROS production that activates HIF-1α, promoting viral replication - mechanisms that could be exacerbated in spaceflight-altered metabolism.

SARS-CoV-2 extensively dysregulates calcium signaling through viral viroporins (E and ORF3a proteins) that form ion channels, altering host cell Ca2+ homeostasis and promoting viral entry and replication, which could interact with spaceflight-induced calcium metabolism changes.

Multiple SARS-CoV-2 proteins (ORF6, ORF8, nucleocapsid) potently inhibit type I interferon signaling pathways, and 10% of severe COVID-19 patients have autoantibodies against IFN-α2 and IFN-ω, highlighting immune evasion strategies relevant to spaceflight immune dysregulation.

The research was NASA-funded through Translational Research Institute of Space Health (NNX16AO69A) and NASA Space Biology Postdoctoral Fellowship (80NSSC19K0426), indicating direct relevance to space health priorities and understanding pathogen behavior in space environments.

SARS-CoV-2 infection reduces nitric oxide bioavailability through increased oxidative stress, leading to peroxynitrite formation and endothelial dysfunction - mechanisms that could compound spaceflight-induced vascular changes and endothelial impairment.

Organoid models of lung, colonic, pancreatic, and other tissues provided valuable disease modeling that correlated with patient autopsy samples, suggesting organoid platforms could be adapted for spaceflight pathogen research where human subjects are limited.
